title: Liam Williams could miss start of Six Nations due to ankle injury which cut short his World Cup
text:
Liam Williams will miss the best part of three months having injured his ankle at the Rugby World Cup - making him touch-and-go at this stage to make the start of next year’s Six Nations.

The Wales and Saracens star would have stayed in Japan if Wales had made the final - having been given permission from his club - but flew back on Monday after the defeat to the Springboks.

He has undergone surgery in the UK, and will now begin his rehabilitation in north London.

Full-back Liam Williams missed Wales' World Cup semi-final defeat to South Africa on Sunday

Wales head coach Warren Gatland confirmed Williams is set to miss the next three months

Head coach Warren Gatland said: ‘I think it will be three months. That surgery takes about that long.

‘If we’d made the final, he would still be here with us. In fairness to Saracens, they’d agreed that.

‘But if we weren’t they wanted to get him back for surgery as quickly as possible.’

As Sportsmail revealed last week, Williams took the ankle blow in training before the South Africa match.

The full-back was forced to watch on from the sidelines, whilst on crutches, in Yokohama

Wales missed him as they lost the game 19-16 in Yokohama last Sunday.

While Williams’ recovery may go better than expected, a three-month lay-off will mean he will miss the opening rounds of Saracens’ Champions Cup defence, and the festive period of the Premiership.

And he could be a doubt for the first round of the 2020 Six Nations. Wales kick off the tournament against Italy in Cardiff on February 1, 13 weeks away.
description: WILL KELLEHER IN TOKYO: The Wales and Saracens star would have stayed in Japan if Wales had made the final, but flew back on Monday and has since undergone surgery on the injury.
